title: My Town Has Just One Rule. Do Not Look Across The Valley.
full_text: I learned early that Westvale had one rule nobody talked about but everyone followed: don't look at Eastmarch. The settlement sat across Grayvale Valley, maybe three miles of dark water separating us from whatever lived over there. Adults would turn their backs when they walked past places where you could see it. Kids got yanked inside if they stared too long from the wrong window. Even the dogs seemed to know better than to bark in that direction. My friends and I broke that rule every chance we got. There were five of us back then. Douglas Rush was our unofficial leader, though he barely said 10 words most days. When he did speak, we listened. He had this way of making decisions that felt final, like arguing would be pointless. Scott Noble was the opposite, couldn't shut up if his life depended on it. Always cracking jokes, always moving, always finding new ways to get us in trouble. Curtis Walker asked questions about everything, the kind of careful, thoughtful questions that made adults uncomfortable. And Jackson Reyes lied about everything, but he did it so well and with such obvious enjoyment that we didn't mind. His stories were better than the truth most of the time. Then there was me, Jerry Bell. I remembered things. Not just the big stuff, but details that seemed to stick in my head long after everyone else forgot them. Sometimes I wished I could forget things the way other people did. Carrying all those memories felt heavy, especially the ones from later that nobody wanted to talk about. We had our favorite spots for watching Eastmarch. South Quarry Rocks gave us the best view on clear days. You could see the buildings, small, dark shapes that looked wrong somehow, like they'd been built by people who had different ideas about how buildings should look. Upper Barley Fields worked when the wind was right and the trees weren't blocking everything. Westvale Shore was risky because adults walked by more often, but on foggy mornings, you could sometimes catch glimpses when the mist shifted just right. We'd spend hours up there, passing around Curtis's father's binoculars when we could sneak them out of the house. Douglas would study the place like he was planning something. Scott would make up stories about what the people over there were doing. Curtis would ask questions nobody could answer. Why didn't we ever see smoke from their chimneys? Why didn't boats ever cross the water? Why did the buildings look like they were built wrong? Jackson would spin elaborate tales about secret tunnels and underground cities and people who lived backwards through time. I'd watch and remember every detail, the way the buildings seemed to lean away from each other, how the streets looked too wide and too empty, the fact that we never saw anyone moving around even though the place was clearly inhabited. Someone had to be living there. The buildings were maintained. The paths were clear. But it was like watching a town full of ghosts. The adults in Westvale talked around Eastmarch the way they talked around other uncomfortable subjects. When pressed, they'd say things like, "Those people keep to themselves," or, "Best to mind our own business." But their faces would tighten up and they'd change the subject fast. My mother once caught me staring across the valley from our kitchen window and pulled the curtains shut so hard the rod nearly came down. She didn't say anything, just gave me a look that made it clear the conversation was over before it started. That kind of reaction only made us more curious. Kids aren't wired to leave mysteries alone, especially when adults are obviously hiding something. The more they avoided talking about Eastmarch, the more we wanted to know what was over there. It became an obsession for all of us, but Douglas seemed to take it more seriously than the rest. He'd get this distant look when he watched the place, like he was working out a puzzle in his head. The weather had been strange that autumn, more fog than usual. And when it cleared, the air stayed so still you could see details across the valley that normally got lost in the haze. We'd been meeting up almost every day after school, finding excuses to walk by places where we could get a good look. Our parents probably thought we were just wandering around the way kids do, but we had purpose. We were studying Eastmarch, learning its rhythms, trying to figure out what made it different. That's how we ended up behind the Westvale storehouse on a Tuesday afternoon in late October. The building blocked us from view of the main street, and there was an old grain cart someone had abandoned back there years ago. The wood was weathered gray and one wheel had come off, leaving it tilted at an angle that made a decent bench if you didn't mind sitting crooked. Douglas had called the meeting. He didn't usually do that. We just sort of found each other most days. But he'd made a point of telling each of us to be there at 4 o'clock, which meant he had something specific on his mind. That should've been my first warning. When Douglas planned ahead, it usually meant trouble. Scott got there first, already perched on the high end of the tilted cart and swinging his legs. He'd been in a weird mood all week, more restless than usual, making jokes that didn't quite land right. Curtis showed up a few minutes later, pushing his glasses up his nose the way he did when he was nervous about something. Jackson arrived with some elaborate story about why he was late, something involving a runaway chicken and his neighbor's laundry line that was probably complete fiction, but entertaining enough that we didn't care. Douglas came last, which was unusual for him. He walked around the corner of the storehouse with that purposeful stride he got when he'd made up his mind about something.The rest of us were already settled on or around the grain cart, but he stayed standing. That was another warning sign I should've paid attention to. Douglas only stayed standing when he had something important to say. He looked at each of us in turn, that serious expression he got when he was thinking hard about something. The afternoon was getting cooler, and shadows from the storehouse were starting to stretch across the ground where we sat. Somewhere in the distance, I could hear Mrs. Henderson calling her cat in for dinner. "We need to go see it," Douglas said, just like that. No build-up, no explanation. He might as well have been commenting on the weather, but we all knew immediately what he meant. There was only one it that mattered to any of us. Scott stopped swinging his legs. Curtis went very still behind his glasses. Jackson's usual grin faded into something more serious. I felt my stomach do something complicated, like it was trying to tie itself in knots. "Go see what?" Curtis asked, even though we all knew. "Eastmarch," Douglas said. "Cross the valley, see what's actually over there." The words hung in the air between us like something physical. I thought about it before. We all had. But thinking about something and hearing it said out loud were different things. Thinking about it was safe. Saying it out loud made it real, made it possible. "That's crazy," Scott said, but his voice didn't have its usual joking tone. He sounded like he was testing the idea, seeing how it felt in his mouth. "Why?" Douglas asked. "Why is it crazy?" Curtis pushed his glasses up again. "Because nobody goes there. Because our parents told us not to. Because there's probably a reason people avoid that place." "What reason?" Douglas said. "Name one actual reason." Curtis opened his mouth and closed it again. That was the problem with all the warnings about Eastmarch. They were all vague. Don't go there. Don't look too long. Mind your own business. But nobody ever explained why. Nobody ever gave us a concrete reason to stay away. "Maybe there isn't a reason," Jackson said slowly. "Maybe it's just one of those things adults say because their parents said it, and their parents said it because their parents said it." "Or maybe there's a really good reason, and they don't want to scare us," Curtis countered. "Then why not just tell us?" Scott asked. "If there's something dangerous over there, wouldn't it make more sense to explain what it is?" Douglas nodded like Scott had made his point for him. "They don't tell us because they don't know either. They're just following the same rule we are, but they've been doing it so long they forgot why it started." I wanted to argue with him, but part of me thought he might be right. The adults in Westvale had that same uncomfortable look whenever Eastmarch came up, like they were repeating something they'd been taught but never really understood. Maybe the original reason for avoiding the place had gotten lost somewhere along the way, and now everyone was just going through the motions. "So what are you suggesting?" I asked, though I was pretty sure I already knew. Douglas looked directly at me when he answered. "We cross the valley. We go see for ourselves what's over there. We find out if there's actually something to be afraid of or if it's just a stupid rule that doesn't mean anything anymore." My stomach tightened again. The idea terrified me and excited me in equal measure. We'd spent so much time watching Eastmarch from a distance, speculating about what might be there. The chance to actually see it, to walk those two wide streets and look at those wrong-angled buildings up close was tempting in a way that made my hands shake a little. "How would we even get there?" Curtis asked. "It's three miles across the water." "Boat," Douglas said simply. "There are plenty of them down at the dock. We take one early in the morning before anyone's awake, row across, look around, come back." "Steal a boat, you mean," Curtis said. "Borrow a boat," Douglas corrected. "We'd bring it back." Scott let out a nervous laugh. "Oh well, if we're bringing it back, that makes it totally fine." But I could tell he was considering it. We all were. The plan was simple enough to actually work, which made it more frightening than if Douglas had suggested something obviously impossible. "When?" Scott asked, and I felt something cold settle in my chest. He wasn't arguing against the idea anymore. He was asking for details. "Two days," Douglas said. "Thursday morning before sunrise. Meet at the dock at five o'clock." "Why Thursday?" Jackson asked. "Because that gives us time to think about it," Douglas said. "If anyone wants to back out, they can. But if we're going to do this, we do it right. Early enough that nobody sees us leave, late enough in the week that people might not notice we're gone until we're back." Curtis was shaking his head slowly. "This is a bad idea. This is a really bad idea." "Maybe," Douglas agreed. "But it's our bad idea, and I'm tired of wondering." I understood what he meant. The curiosity had been building in all of us for months, maybe years. Every time we watched Eastmarch from our various hiding spots, every time an adult changed the subject when it came up, every time we caught a glimpse of those strange buildings across the water, the questions got stronger. What was over there? Why didn't anyone talk about it? What were we all so afraid of?"I need to think about it," Curtis said. "That's fine," Douglas said. "We all do. But Thursday morning, five o'clock, anyone who wants to come, be at the dock. Anyone who doesn't, stay home." He turned and walked away without waiting for a response, leaving the four of us sitting on the broken grain cart in the growing shadows. For a long moment, nobody said anything. The whole idea was so big, so different from anything we'd done before that it was hard to know how to react. "He's serious," Scott said finally. "Yeah," Jackson agreed. "He's serious." Curtis was still shaking his head. "We're going to get in so much trouble." "Only if we get caught," Scott pointed out. "We're going to get caught," Curtis said. "And when we do, we're going to be in the worst trouble of our lives." He was probably right. But as I sat there thinking about it, I realized that didn't matter as much as it should have. The pull of Eastmarch, the need to finally know what was over there, felt stronger than my fear of getting in trouble. It felt stronger than almost anything. "Are you going to do it?" Jackson asked me. I looked across the space between buildings, toward where I knew the valley lay hidden behind the storehouse and the trees. Somewhere across that dark water, Eastmarch waited. Those strange buildings, those empty streets, whatever secrets the adults in Westvale had been keeping from us for as long as I could remember. "Yeah," I said. And the word felt heavy coming out of my mouth. "I think I am." Scott nodded slowly. "Me too." Jackson grinned, but it wasn't his usual careless smile. This one had an edge to it, like he was excited and terrified at the same time. "Well, I'm not missing this." We all looked at Curtis. He was quiet for a long time, staring at his hands folded in his lap. When he finally looked up, his face was pale behind his glasses. "I don't want to," he said. "But I don't wanna be the only one who doesn't go either." That settled it. Thursday morning, five o'clock. We'd row across Greysvale Valley and see Eastmarch for ourselves. We'd finally get answers to all the questions that had been eating at us for so long. I should have been more afraid than I was. I should have listened to the part of my brain that was screaming warnings about how wrong this felt. But the curiosity was stronger than the fear, and the need to know was stronger than the need to be safe. Two days felt like forever and no time at all. As we walked away from the grain cart and the storehouse, splitting up to head home for dinner, I could feel the weight of what we'd decided settling over me. In 48 hours, we'd either have our answers or we'd be in more trouble than we'd ever imagined. The forbidden settlement across the water had been calling to us for years. Thursday morning, we were finally going to answer. My eyes opened in complete darkness, and I knew without checking the time that it was Thursday morning. The house sat silent around me, not even the usual creaking of settling wood or the distant sound of early risers starting their day. My parents wouldn't be awake for another two hours at least, which meant I had enough time to slip out without anyone noticing. I'd barely slept. Every time I'd started to drift off, my mind would jolt back to what we were about to do, cross the valley, actually set foot in Eastmarch. After years of watching from a distance, we were finally going to get our answers. The thought made my stomach twist with equal parts excitement and dread. I dressed quietly in the dark, pulling on my heaviest shirt and the pants I'd laid out the night before. My boots were by the bedroom door where I'd left them, and I carried them downstairs rather than risk the noise of walking in them. The kitchen felt enormous in the predawn silence. Every small sound magnified. I grabbed the water flask I'd filled the night before and the wrapped bread from the pantry shelf, stuffing both into the canvas bag I'd borrowed from my father's workshop. The front door opened without its usual groan, and I stepped into the cold morning air. The world felt different at this hour, hushed and expectant. Stars still dotted the sky, but there was a faint lightening along the eastern horizon that meant sunrise wasn't far off. We needed to be across the water and back before full daylight brought the risk of being spotted by early fishermen or dockworkers. My feet knew the way to Westvale Dock even in the dim light. I'd walked these streets countless times, but never with this sense of purpose, never knowing I was about to break the most fundamental rule of our town. The houses I passed were dark and silent, their windows like closed eyes. I wondered what the people inside would think if they knew what we were planning. Would they try to stop us? Would they understand? The smell hit me before I could see the dock clearly. River rope, thick and wet from the constant moisture. Barnacles clinging to the wooden posts, their sharp edges cutting through the softer scents. Bait barrels lined up near the fishing boats, their contents adding a fish and salt tang to the air. All of it mixed together into something that meant water and boats and the beginning of our journey. Predawn blue hung over everything, that strange half-light that made familiar shapes look foreign and uncertain. Westvale felt like a different town entirely, as if we'd already crossed into unknown territory just by being awake at this hour.... the dock stretched out into the water like a wooden finger pointing toward Eastmarch, and I could see the dark shapes of boats tied along its length. "Jerry." Douglas's voice came from the shadows near the dock's edge. He was already there, standing beside one of the mooring posts with his own bag slung over his shoulder. Even in the dim light, I could see the tension in his posture, the way he held himself ready for action. "You made it," I said, keeping my voice low even though there was no one around to hear us. "Course I did." Douglas never showed doubt, not even now when we were about to do something that could get us in more trouble than we'd ever faced. "The others will be here." As if summoned by his words, Scott appeared from the direction of Miller Street, moving at his usual quick pace, but trying to stay quiet. His canvas bag bounced against his hip as he walked, and I could hear the muffled clink of whatever he'd brought with him. Behind him, moving more slowly and carefully, came Curtis. Even from a distance, I could see him pushing his glasses up his nose, a nervous habit that meant he was having second thoughts. "This is really happening," Scott said when he reached us. His voice carried a mix of excitement and disbelief as if he couldn't quite accept that we were actually going through with Douglas' plan. Curtis joined our small group near the mooring post, shifting his weight from foot to foot. "I brought the compass," he said, patting his bag. "It's cracked, but it still works. And rope, my father's good rope." "Hammer," Scott announced, hefting his bag. "Figured we might need to break something open or knock something down." I showed them my water and bread. "Figured we'd get hungry." Douglas nodded at each contribution, then shouldered his own bag. "Knife, more rope, extra flask." He turned toward the boats tied along the dock. "We need the skiff at the far end, the one nobody uses for regular fishing." We followed him along the wooden planks, our footsteps muffled, but still audible in the morning quiet. The dock felt longer than usual, stretching out over water that looked black and endless in the predawn light. Boats rocked gently in their moorings, their masts and rigging creating a forest of vertical lines against the slowly lightening sky. The skiff Douglas led us to was smaller than the regular fishing boats, built for ferry work rather than hauling nets. Its hull was painted a faded blue-green that had probably been bright once, but now looked weathered and practical. Two sets of oars lay across the center seats, and the boat itself looked solid enough to get us across the valley and back. "Ferry's skiff," Douglas said, running his hand along the gunwale. "Owner uses it maybe once a month. Won't be missed for a few hours." I watched him untie the mooring lines with quick, efficient movements. His hands worked the knots like he'd done this before, though I knew he hadn't. Douglas just had that way about him, making everything look easier than it probably was. The boat drifted slightly as the lines came free, held in place only by Douglas' grip on the bow. "Get in," he said. "Careful not to rock it too much." Scott went first, stepping into the boat with more confidence than skill. The skiff tilted under his weight, and he grabbed the nearest seat to steady himself. Curtis followed more cautiously, testing each step before committing his full weight. I came next, feeling the boat respond to my movements, the way it wanted to tip and sway with every shift in balance. Douglas pushed us away from the dock before climbing in himself, settling into the stern seat and taking up the oars. Jackson still hadn't arrived, and for a moment, I wondered if he'd changed his mind, decided the risk was too great. Then I saw him jogging toward the dock, his bag bouncing against his back. "Wait," he called in a loud whisper. "Almost missed it." He practically jumped into the boat, making it rock violently before Douglas could steady us. "Sorry, couldn't find my good boots in the dark." "Sit down and stay still," Douglas said, already dipping the oars into the water. "We're burning daylight." The first few strokes took us away from the dock and into the open water of the river. I felt the moment when we left the shallows behind, when the bottom dropped away beneath us and we were truly committed to the crossing. The dock grew smaller behind us, Westvale's familiar buildings fading into the blue-gray of early morning. I made myself not look back. Whatever happened next, we were past the point of changing our minds. The water stretched ahead of us, dark and wide, with Eastmarch waiting on the far shore. I'd spent years staring across this valley, wondering what we'd find over there. Now, I was finally going to get my answer. Douglas and Jackson settled into a rhythm with the oars, pulling us steadily across the current. The water was deeper here than I'd expected, dark enough that I couldn't see the bottom even in the growing light. Small waves lapped against the hull with a gentle slapping sound that seemed too loud in the morning quiet. Ground fog was starting to lift from the water, thin wisps that curled up from the surface and drifted away on the slight breeze. Through the shifting mist, I could see Eastmarch Slope emerging more clearly than ever before. The buildings looked even stranger from this angle, their odd angles and tilted walls more pronounced when viewed from water level. Streets that had seemed merely wide from our distant observation points-... now looked enormous. Empty spaces between structures that didn't quite make sense. "Look at that," Curtis said quietly, pointing toward the approaching shore. "The houses really are wrong." He was right. What we'd attributed to distance and poor viewing angles was actually there, built into the very structure of the settlement. Roof lines that should've been parallel, instead slanted away from each other. Windows that should've been square looked trapezoidal. Even the docks we were approaching seemed to extend into the water at odd angles, as if whoever built them had been working from plans that didn't quite match reality. "Maybe they just build different over there," Scott said, but his voice lacked conviction. "Different style or something." I didn't think it was a matter of style. The wrongness went deeper than that, into the basic geometry of how things were put together. It made my eyes want to slide away, to look at something else that made more sense. We were halfway across when Scott's voice changed, "Guys, look at the water." I followed his pointed finger to the dark surface beside our boat. At first, I didn't see anything unusual, just the gentle ripples created by our passage. Then something moved beneath the surface, a shadow that was too regular to be debris or plant matter. "What is that?" Curtis asked, leaning forward to get a better look. Douglas kept rowing, but turned his head to follow our stares. "Fins," he said matter-of-factly. Swimming beside us, the shapes became clearer as more of them appeared, dark forms gliding under the water in slow, deliberate arcs. They moved with purpose, keeping pace with our boat, but staying just deep enough to remain partially hidden. I counted at least six of them, maybe more. "Fish?" Jackson asked, but his voice suggested he already knew better. "Blacktip river sharks," Douglas said, pulling harder on the oars. "They follow boats sometimes, looking for scraps or bait." Sharks. The word sent a chill through me that had nothing to do with the morning air. I'd heard stories about blacktips in the river, but always dismissed them as fishermen's tales meant to keep kids away from deep water. Seeing them now, their dark shapes cutting through the water with predatory grace made those stories feel very real. "Are they dangerous?" Curtis asked, his voice climbing toward panic. "Not usually," Douglas said, but he was rowing faster now, making the boat surge forward with each stroke. "But I'd rather not find out." Jackson picked up the second set of oars and joined Douglas in pulling us toward Eastmarch. The increased speed made the boat pitch and sway more dramatically, and I had to grip the gunnel to keep my balance. Cold water sloshed over the center plank with each stroke, soaking through my boots and making the bottom of the boat slippery. The sharks seemed to respond to our increased speed by swimming closer to the surface. I could see them more clearly now, sleek shapes with pointed snouts and the distinctive dark tips on their fins that gave them their name. They moved with an efficiency that was both beautiful and terrifying, cutting through the water like they owned it. "How much farther?" Scott asked, his eyes fixed on the water around us. "Almost there," Douglas replied, but his breathing was getting heavier from the effort of rowing fast. Sweat stood out on his forehead despite the cool morning air. That's when I felt it, a dull impact against the hull, like someone had struck the boat with a heavy stick. The sound was muffled by the water, but unmistakable. A solid thunk that vibrated through the wooden planks beneath my feet. "They're bumping us," I said, trying to keep the fear out of my voice. Another impact, stronger this time, made the boat lurch to one side. Curtis grabbed the nearest seat with both hands, his knuckles white with tension. Scott had gone completely silent, which was more frightening than if he'd been making jokes. "Row harder," Douglas commanded, and Jackson responded by pulling so hard on his oars that he nearly lost his balance. The shore was getting closer, but not fast enough. I could see the strange angles of Eastmarch's buildings more clearly now, the twisted geometry that made my head hurt if I looked at it too long. The docks extended into the water like gnarled fingers. Their wooden posts covered with something that looked like moss, but moved in the current like it was alive. Another bump, this one hard enough to make water splash over the side. The boat was taking on water faster now, and I could feel it getting heavier, more sluggish in response to the oars. We were still 100 yards from shore, maybe more. "There," Curtis said suddenly, pointing ahead. "Rocks." I saw them too, dark shapes just beneath the surface near what looked like a ford or shallow crossing. The water was lighter there, indicating depth changes that could mean either safety or disaster, depending on how we approached them. "Eastmarch Ford," Douglas said between strokes. "We can beach there." But the boat was getting harder to control. Water had pooled around our feet, and every shark bump made us list further to one side. Jackson was pulling on his oars with desperate strength, but we were fighting both the current and the weight of the water we'd taken on. The impact, when it came, wasn't from below. We hit something solid and unyielding, a hidden shoal that the ford's shallow water had concealed. The sound was like a gunshot, wood splintering against stone.... the boat lurched violently to one side, and I felt the hull crack along its length. Our supplies slid toward the low side of the boat, canvas bags and rope and tools all tumbling together as the skiff listed at an impossible angle. Water poured in through the crack, and I realized with a sick certainty that we weren't going to make it to shore in the boat. "Abandon ship!" Douglas shouted, already standing and preparing to jump into the shallow water of the ford. Get to shore now. The boat was going down, the sharks were still circling, and Eastmarch waited ahead of us with its wrong angles and empty streets. We'd wanted answers, and now we were going to get them whether we were ready or not. I hit the water and it slammed into my chest with the force of a closed door. The cold shocked every nerve in my body awake at once. And before I could even process what was happening, the current grabbed my ankles and yanked them sideways. My feet scrambled for purchase on nothing but rushing water, and panic shot through me as I realized how deep the ford actually was once you got away from the immediate shallows. Something slick brushed against my left foot, and my mind immediately went to the sharks. They were still down there, probably confused by all the splashing and movement, but definitely present. I kicked harder, not caring about technique or efficiency, just desperate to get away from whatever had touched me. The water was murky from all the sediment we'd stirred up abandoning the boat, and I couldn't see more than a few inches below the surface. My lungs burned as I fought against the current. The shore looked impossibly far away, even though I knew it couldn't be more than 20 or 30 feet, but the water kept trying to push me downstream, away from where I needed to go. And every stroke felt like I was swimming through thick soup. My clothes weighed me down, the canvas bag I'd somehow managed to keep strapped across my shoulder dragging like an anchor. Behind me, I could hear the others splashing and shouting, but I didn't dare turn around to look. All my focus had to stay on reaching that rocky shore ahead of me. The buildings of Eastmarch loomed above the waterline, their wrong angles even more disturbing now that I was this close. The roof lines seemed to lean away from each other at impossible degrees, creating shadows that fell in directions that made no sense. Another few desperate strokes and my fingers finally scraped against something solid. River cobble, smooth and slippery but real. I grabbed at the stones with both hands, trying to haul myself up out of the water, but my grip kept slipping on the wet rocks. My elbows scraped raw against the sharp edges as I clawed my way forward, leaving streaks of blood on the gray stone. The current was still trying to pull me back, and for a terrifying moment, I thought I might lose my grip entirely. My fingers found a larger rock, something I could actually hold onto, and I used it to drag myself further up onto the shore. Water streamed from my clothes as I finally got my knees under me, gasping and shaking from the cold and exertion. Douglas hauled himself up beside me, water pouring from his dark hair. His face was grim as he looked back toward where we'd abandoned the boat. Scott came next, his usual jokes completely absent as he collapsed onto the cobbles, breathing hard. Curtis emerged from the water looking pale and shaken. His glasses somehow still on his face, but completely fogged over. Jackson was the last to reach shore, and when he did, he immediately turned back to stare at the water. Our skiff was already disappearing into the fog that hung over the river. All our supplies were going down with it, the rope, the extra water, Scott's hammer, Curtis' compass, everything we'd brought to help us explore Eastmarch. We were stranded here now, with nothing but the clothes on our backs and whatever we'd managed to keep in our pockets. I watched the boat's outline fade into the gray mist until I couldn't see it anymore. The finality of it hit me like a physical blow. We'd crossed the valley, just like Douglas had planned, but now we had no way back. Whatever we found in Eastmarch, we were going to have to deal with it without supplies and without an easy escape route. Standing on the shore, dripping and cold, I tried to get my bearings. This was Eastmarch's shore, the place we'd stared at from across the valley for years. But now that I was actually here, something felt immediately wrong about it. Not wrong in an obvious way, but wrong in a way that made my skin crawl without being able to pinpoint exactly why. The landscape looked familiar and unfamiliar at the same time. There was a willow tree near the water's edge, its branches drooping toward the river just like the one on Westvale's shore. But this willow was crooked, leaning at an angle that seemed too severe for a healthy tree. Its leaves were the right color, the right shape, but they hung differently somehow, as if gravity worked slightly differently here. A cluster of black rocks jutted up from the shore about 50 feet to our left, worn smooth by decades of river water. They looked almost identical to the rock formation on our side of the valley, the one we'd climbed on as children. But these rocks were arranged in a pattern that was just different enough to be unsettling. The largest one was in the wrong position, creating a shadow that fell where no shadow should fall. Even the grass was wrong. It was green, the same shade we had back home, but it seemed to grow in slightly different patterns.The spacing between individual blades was off, creating a texture that looked normal from a distance, but became increasingly strange the more you focused on it. The color was right, but somehow too bright, too vivid, like someone had tried to recreate normal grass from memory and gotten the details almost, but not quite correct. The slope that led up from the shore matched Westvale's geography closely enough to be recognizable, but the angle was different, steeper in some places, gentler in others, creating a landscape that felt like a distorted reflection of home. The trees that dotted the hillside were spaced wrong. Their branches reaching in directions that created an unnatural rhythm across the slope. What really caught my attention though was the path. On Westvale shore, there was no path leading up from the water. The slope was just grass and scattered rocks, too steep to climb easily in most places. But here, a narrow trail cut through the hillside, winding its way up toward the buildings above. It looked old, well-worn, as if people had been using it regularly for years. The path was just wide enough for single file, carved into the slope with deliberate precision. Someone had taken the time to clear the rocks and level the ground, creating a route that switchbacked up the hill in a series of gentle curves. It was the kind of path that spoke of regular use, of people who needed to travel between the shore and the settlement above on a routine basis. Douglas was already looking at the path, water still dripping from his clothes. He didn't say anything, but I could see the decision forming in his expression. We'd come this far, lost our boat, nearly been eaten by sharks, and now we were standing on forbidden ground with no easy way home. The only direction left was up. He started walking toward the path without waiting for discussion or agreement. That was Douglas. Once he'd made a decision, he acted on it immediately. "The expedition, crossing to Eastmarch, Curtis and Jackson." Douglas tilted his head slightly, the way people do when they hear something that doesn't make sense to them. "Curtis and Jackson, what about them?" "They're gone, Douglas. Curtis is dead. Jackson drowned in the river." Mary Fletcher looked between us with growing confusion. Douglas' expression shifted to concern, but not the kind of concern I expected. It was the look adults gave when they thought a child was having strange fantasies. "Jerry, what are you talking about? Curtis moved away last month with his family. His father got work in Millbrook, and Jackson..." Douglas paused, his brow furrowing as if trying to remember something difficult. "Jackson's family decided to try their luck in the Eastern settlements. They left about the same time." The words hit me like a physical blow. I looked at Mary, hoping to see some flicker of recognition, some sign that she remembered our classmates differently, but her expression matched Douglas' perfectly. "That's right," she said. "Curtis was so excited about the move. Said Millbrook had a real library with hundreds of books." My throat felt tight. "No, that's not what happened. We went across the valley yesterday morning. All five of us, we took the ferry and crossed to Eastmarch and Curtis died there." Douglas reached out and put a hand on my shoulder, the way you might comfort someone who was clearly unwell. "Jerry, we've never been across the valley. Nobody goes to Eastmarch, you know that." "But we did go. You led us there. You said we needed to see what was really over there.""I would never suggest something like that," Douglas said, and his voice carried absolute conviction. "It's dangerous across the valley. Everyone knows that." Scott appeared from around the corner of the schoolhouse, his face bright and cheerful. No trace of the tears I'd seen him crying yesterday. No sign of the fear that had made his hands shake as we rode back across the dark water. "What's dangerous?" Scott asked, joining our group. "Jeri thinks we went to Eastmarch yesterday," Mary said with a small laugh. Scott's expression shifted to the same concerned confusion I'd seen from Douglas. "Eastmarch? Why would we go there? Nobody goes to Eastmarch." I looked at Scott carefully, searching his face for any crack in this performance. But it wasn't a performance. His confusion was genuine. His concern for my apparent delusion was real. "Scott, you were there. You cried when Curtis died. You saw the tall woman carry his body." Scott shook his head slowly. "Jeri, I think you might've had a bad dream. Curtis moved to Millbrook, remember? His family packed up their wagon and everything." The school bell rang, calling us inside. Douglas, Scott, and Mary headed toward the door, still throwing worried glances back at me. I stood frozen in the yard, watching them go. Inside the schoolhouse, I took my usual seat and looked around the room. Curtis's desk sat empty in the third row, just as it had for the past month since his family moved to Millbrook. Jackson's seat was vacant too, had been since his family departed for the Eastern Settlements. Except that wasn't what had happened. Curtis hadn't moved to Millbrook. His family hadn't packed a wagon. Curtis had died in the arms of a creature that shouldn't exist, on the other side of a valley that no one was supposed to cross. But everyone else remembered it differently. Everyone else had the same false memories, the same convenient explanations for why Curtis and Jackson were no longer here. Mr. Henderson began the day's lessons, his voice carrying the same authority it always had. When he called roll, he skipped over Curtis's name and Jackson's name without pause, without acknowledgement that they had ever existed in this classroom. During the arithmetic lesson, I found myself staring out the window toward the valley. From this angle, I could just see the edge of the dark water through the trees. Eastmarch lay beyond that water, hidden by distance and morning haze. The tall woman was still there, probably still holding Curtis's body. The house still stood in its impossible clearing, with its reversed photographs and backwards clock. But according to everyone else in Westvale, none of that had ever happened. At recess, I approached other classmates, testing their memories. Sarah Mills remembered Curtis being excited about his family's move to Millbrook. Tom Baker recalled helping Jackson's family load their wagon for the journey east. Every detail was consistent, every story perfectly aligned. They weren't lying. They genuinely remembered these false events as if they had really happened. Somehow, Westvale had rewritten its own history to explain the absence of Curtis and Jackson without acknowledging what had really occurred. I walked to the edge of the schoolyard and looked toward the valley again. The water stretched dark and still between the hills, just as it always had. But now I understood something that no one else seemed to remember. That water wasn't just a boundary between two settlements. It was a barrier between two different kinds of reality. The town had restored its unspoken rule about never looking toward Eastmarch, but the rule went deeper than I'd realized. It wasn't just about not looking. It was about not remembering, not acknowledging, not allowing the truth of what existed across that water to take root in Westvale's collective memory. I thought about the adults who had been waiting for us at the shore yesterday. They hadn't seemed surprised to see us return. They'd known exactly how to handle the situation. They'd had a story ready, a way to explain away what had happened. This wasn't the first time children had crossed the valley. This wasn't the first time some of them hadn't come back. The valley watched back. I could feel it even now, standing in the schoolyard with my back to the water. Something patient and malevolent waited across that dark expanse, something that had taken Curtis and Jackson and who knows how many others over the years. But Westvale had found a way to survive alongside that presence, by forgetting, by rewriting history, by refusing to acknowledge what really happened to the children who satisfied their curiosity about what lay beyond the water. Everyone except me. For some reason, I still remembered. I still carried the weight of what we'd witnessed over there, the tall woman's impossible neck stretching toward us, the duplicate standing motionless under the trees, the house that shouldn't exist, Curtis's glasses falling to the ground. I was the only one who knew the truth about what waited across the dark water, the only one who understood why Westvale enforced its silent prohibition with such rigid determination. Some boundaries existed for protection. Some curiosities demanded prices too terrible to pay. The town had learned this lesson long ago and had developed ways to forget each time the lesson needed to be taught again. But I couldn't forget. I couldn't erase the tall woman's downward smile or the way Jackson's replacement had moved with unnatural wrongness. These memories belonged to me now, and I would carry them alone. I accepted my role as the sole keeper of this terrible knowledge, understanding that I would live each day with the crushing weight of what I had witnessed and somehow survived.
